text: MR. KUBARYCH:  Thanks very much.  I'm very
label: BODY

text: delighted to have a chance to be here.  The Commission
label: BODY

text: has a tremendous depth of experience, and any number of
label: BODY

text: you could make my remarks better than me.
label: BODY

text: So I'd like to focus a little bit on maybe a
label: BODY

text: little comparative advantage.  For the last 12 years with
label: BODY

text: my friend and partner, Henry Kaufman, we've been managing
label: BODY

text: money for large foreign institutions, as well as domestic
label: BODY

text: institutions, and you learn a little bit about the
label: BODY

text: thinking of at least some of the larger foreign
label: BODY

text: investors,
label: BODY

text: including
label: BODY

text: investment
label: BODY

text: funds,
label: BODY

text: insurance
label: BODY

text: companies, banks, and so on.
label: BODY

text: I would agree that for the time being this
label: BODY

text: is not an issue to cause high anxiety, and I think that
label: BODY

text: the reasons are straightforward.  You asked the question:
label: BODY

text: Why are foreign markets so attractive.  Why are U.S.
label: BODY

text: markets so attractive to foreign investors?  And the
label: BODY

text: answer is for the same reason that they're attracted to
label: BODY

text: Americans.
label: BODY

text: The economic data are terrific.  The high
label: BODY

text: tech boom has had a kind of halo effect that has dazzled
label: BODY

text: people so that they do not pay as much attention to
label: BODY

text: longer-term vulnerabilities, and there's a broader
label: BODY

text: dimension as well.
label: BODY

text: Foreign investors are very impressed, as
label: BODY

text: well as Americans, about the broad, almost bipartisan
label: BODY

text: consensus about a number of positive factors in
label: BODY

text: organizing economic policy.  One is a commitment to
label: BODY

text: fiscal discipline.  One can argue about the exact shape
label: BODY

text: of that fiscal policy, but certainly we have at least
label: BODY

text: the most disciplined approach to fiscal policy we've
label: BODY

text: ever had.
label: BODY

text: Another is an independent Central Bank that
label: BODY

text: is fully pursuing monetary policy on a professional and
label: BODY

text: highly operationally competent basis.
label: BODY

text: Also important is our philosophical
label: BODY

text: commitment to open markets and an enterprise driven
label: BODY

text: economy, which is also bipartisan.
label: BODY

text: And a further strength is that the American
label: BODY

text: model is not doctrinaire.  We have a belief in the
label: BODY

text: benefits of a powerful infrastructure of law, of
label: BODY

text: official regulation, and self-policing by market
label: BODY

text: participants, and this is admired by foreign investors.
label: BODY

text: They don't always have this kind of regulatory
label: BODY

text: infrastructure themselves.  Where they have invested in
label: BODY

text: countries with troubles, they have felt the pain
label: BODY

text: stemming from the lack of that legal and regulatory
label: BODY

text: infrastructure.  It is an important source of strength
label: BODY

text: for our markets.
label: BODY

text: Now, it's very important to realize that
label: BODY

text: foreign investors have not been aggressively in the
label: BODY

text: mainstream of investing in the U.S. stock market.  They
label: BODY

text: have taken part.  They have done well.  Their share of
label: BODY

text: U.S. overall equity ownership has drifted up a little
label: BODY

text: bit over the last five years, but the bulk of where
label: BODY

text: foreign investors matter the most for our financial
label: BODY

text: markets is in the bond market.
label: BODY

text: And as a result we now have a situation
label: BODY

text: where a trillion dollars of bond investments have been
label: BODY

text: made by foreign investors in the last few years.  If
label: BODY

text: you take U.S. Treasury obligations, foreign investors
label: BODY

text: are now a third of total ownership of U.S. treasury
label: BODY

text: obligations, which is double the ratio of 10 years ago.
label: BODY

text: So when you ask; Is foreign investment here
label: BODY

text: sustainable, you're really asking about foreign
label: BODY

text: investment in our bond markets.  And all of those
label: BODY

text: factors really boil down to this:  Are we committed to
label: BODY

text: keeping the inflation rate low, making for honest
label: BODY

text: money, or not?
label: BODY

text: And I think that right now foreign
label: BODY

text: investors are quite convinced that we are.  And I think
label: BODY

text: they'll stay convinced as long as the kind of balance
label: BODY

text: in monetary and fiscal policy that Gerry Corrigan just
label: BODY

text: talked about is preserved, notwithstanding the fact
label: BODY

text: that we do have some opportunities, given the large
label: BODY

text: surplus, to do some things.
label: BODY

text: Now, let me finish up with what could go
label: BODY

text: wrong.  Where are the risks?
label: BODY

text: Well, the first risk, because of this halo
label: BODY

text: effect that I mentioned, is if the high tech bubble
label: BODY

text: should burst.  Now, let me just remind people about one
label: BODY

text: of the benefits of getting past 50, as Bob Dugger
label: BODY

text: mentioned, is that you have accumulated a little bit of
label: BODY

text: memory of the past.
label: BODY

text: Let me take you back to 1967 and 1968.
label: BODY

text: This country had a high-tech bubble.  Computer
label: BODY

text: companies, technology companies galore reached price
label: BODY

text: earnings ratios that are familiar to us now, but we
label: BODY

text: really haven't seen in the meantime.
label: BODY

text: Take one company you've all heard of,
label: BODY

text: Control Data.  It peaked in 1967-1968 at a high of 163.
label: BODY

text: Within two years it had fallen to 28, a decline of 83
label: BODY

text: percent.
label: BODY

text: Take another one just for an illustration.
label: BODY

text: EDS, Electronic Data Systems, which has had quite a
label: BODY

text: history ever since, hit a high of $162 a share in that
label: BODY

text: period, reached a 1970 low of 24, a decline of 85
label: BODY

text: percent.
label: BODY

text: In fact, I have a list of about three dozen
label: BODY

text: stocks, very similar in spirit to the kind of stocks
label: BODY

text: which have been performing so bubblingly well in recent
label: BODY

text: days, where the average decline was 88 percent from the
label: BODY

text: peak of 1967-68 to the low point in 1970. (SEE INSERT
label: BODY

text: If you go back and read the brokerage
label: BODY

text: reports and read the headlines of that period, you will
label: BODY

text: see language that looks absolutely identical to what
label: BODY

text: you're reading today.  It was also a period of
label: BODY

text: computerization of American industry that in many
label: BODY

text: respects was more profound than what we have now, which
label: BODY

text: is certainly wonderful.  And I use the Internet myself
label: BODY

text: at least six to eight hours a day as part of the
label: BODY

text: research that I'm doing for a book.  But frankly, when
label: BODY

text: you saw how banks were operated in the early '60s, and
label: BODY

text: as they are in some parts of the world today, and you
label: BODY

text: see the computerization that took place, that was
label: BODY

text: definitely a revolution then, and high tech companies
label: BODY

text: were bid up to staggering magnitudes then.
label: BODY

text: Now, I know that Dell, which has gone up
label: BODY

text: 90,772 percent in the decade of the '90s, is a fine
label: BODY

text: company and others as well, but not all of the high
label: BODY

text: tech companies will deliver the earnings that the
label: BODY

text: buyers expect.
label: BODY

text: And when they don't, and if there's any
label: BODY

text: kind of a slip up, foreign investors are going to
label: BODY

text: rethink, and it's going to have an impact in their
label: BODY

text: desired holdings of U.S. assets.
label: BODY

text: Now, number two, another dark cloud on my
label: BODY

text: list is a slowdown in the U.S. economy that might
label: BODY

text: incite demands for more protectionist stands on trade
label: BODY

text: policy.  Let's face it.  Foreign investors would see
label: BODY

text: this as terribly inflationary when you've got an
label: BODY

text: economy with four percent unemployment, and they would
label: BODY

text: not believe that the Fed would have an easy time
label: BODY

text: dealing with the inflationary consequences of really
label: BODY

text: protectionist measures.  That would have a chilling
label: BODY

text: effect on foreign investment, the smoothness of its
label: BODY

text: coming in.
label: BODY

text: Number three is any overt attempt to weaken
label: BODY

text: the dollar.  Now, it is true that most foreign
label: BODY

text: investors, certainly our clients, believe that the
label: BODY

text: dollar will ease back somewhat, and you see that
label: BODY

text: displayed vividly in the structure of forward exchange
label: BODY

text: markets.  It's already in there in the expectation
label: BODY

text: structure, but a manipulative approach that would
label: BODY

text: essentially abandon the current U.S. Treasury posture -
label: BODY

text: - which is that a strong dollar is in the interest of
label: BODY

text: the U.S. -- would, I think, trigger sizable outflows of
label: BODY

text: funds from the U.S. markets, and that might have an
label: BODY

text: effect on bond and stock market valuations.
label: BODY

text: Number four, and this is broader, but you
label: BODY

text: do get this very often when you talk to foreign
label: BODY

text: investors, and that is the mishandling of foreign
label: BODY

text: relations more broadly cast.  Right now we have seven,
label: BODY

text: at least seven -- rifts with our European partners over
label: BODY

text: a range of issues ranging from IMF governance to
label: BODY

text: bananas to hormones and beef to aircraft noise and to
label: BODY

text: the adverse WTO ruling against foreign sales
label: BODY

text: corporations.
label: BODY

text: We've latent problems with Japan that could
label: BODY

text: break out into the open.  We have the issue that, as
label: BODY

text: Gerry and others have mentioned, of WTO membership for
label: BODY

text: China, and so on.  There's a matter of how to deal
label: BODY

text: intelligently with an erratic Russia; the broad
label: BODY

text: question of how to deal with a reinvigorated OPEC.
label: BODY

text: These are very tough foreign policy
label: BODY

text: considerations.  Foreign investors expect the U.S. to
label: BODY

text: behave as a super power and not with narrow nationalist
label: BODY

text: economic policy agendas.
label: BODY

text: And finally, and the one that I'm most
label: BODY

text: confident about, is foreign investors expect and will
label: BODY

text: insist on a firm monetary policy response to any
label: BODY

text: significant increase in the inflation rate.  I believe
label: BODY

text: there will be.  If there isn't, there would be
label: BODY

text: problems.
label: BODY

text: Those are my comments.
label: BODY

text: CHAIRMAN D'AMATO:  Thank you very much, Mr.
label: BODY

text: Kubarych.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Madrick.
label: BODY
